paragraph: CHAPTER 13.

When breakfast was over the next morning, Ready observed, "Now, Mr Seagrave, we must hold a council of war, and decide upon an exploring party for to-morrow; and, when we have settled that, we will find some useful way of employing ourselves for the rest of the day.  The first question is, of whom is the party to consist?--and upon that I wish to hear your opinion."
tokens: breakfast next morning ready observe hold council war decide explore party settle find useful way employ rest day first question party consist wish hear opinion

paragraph: "Why, Ready," replied Mr Seagrave, "it appears to me that you and I should go."
tokens: ready reply appear go

paragraph: "Surely not both of you, my dear," interrupted Mrs Seagrave.  "You can do without my husband, can you not, Ready?"
tokens: dear interrupt do husband ready

paragraph: "I certainly should have liked to have Mr Seagrave to advise with, ma'am," replied Ready; "but still I have thought upon it, and do not think that William would be quite sufficient protection for you; or, at all events, you would not feel that he was, which is much the same thing; and so, if Mr Seagrave has no objection, it would perhaps be better that he remained with you."
tokens: like have advise reply ready think think sufficient protection event feel same thing have objection good remain

paragraph: "Would you go alone, then, Ready?" said Mr Seagrave.
tokens: go ready say

paragraph: "No, sir, I do not think that would be right either,--some accident might happen; there is no saying what might happen, although there is every appearance of safety.  I should like, therefore, to have some one with me; the question is, whether it be William or Juno?"
tokens: sir think right accident happen be saying happen be appearance safety like have one question

paragraph: "Take me," said Tommy.
tokens: take say

paragraph: "Take you, Tommy!" said Ready, laughing; "then I must take Juno to take care of you.  No; I think they cannot spare you.  Your mamma will want you when we are gone; you are so useful in gathering wood for the fire, and taking care of your little sister and brother, that your mother cannot part with you; so I must have either Juno or William."
tokens: take say ready laugh take take care think spare mamma want gone useful gather wood fire take care little sister brother mother part have

paragraph: "And which would you prefer, Ready?" said Mrs Seagrave.
tokens: prefer ready say

paragraph: "William, certainly, ma'am, if you will let him go with me, as you could ill spare the girl."
tokens: let go spare girl

paragraph: "Indeed, I do not like it; I would rather lose Juno for a time," replied Mrs Seagrave.
tokens: like lose time reply

paragraph: "My dear wife," said Mr Seagrave, "recollect how Providence has preserved us in such awful dangers--how we are landed in safety.  And now, will you not put trust in that Providence, when the dangers are, as I trust, only imaginary?"
tokens: dear wife say recollect preserve such awful danger land safety put trust danger trust imaginary

paragraph: "I was wrong, my dear husband; but sickness and suffering have made me, I fear, not only nervous and frightened, but selfish: I must and will shake it off.  Hitherto I have only been a clog and an incumbrance to you; but I trust I shall soon behave better, and make myself useful.  If you think, then, that it would be better that you should go instead of William, I am quite content.  Go, then, with Ready, and may Heaven protect you both!"
tokens: wrong dear husband sickness suffering make fear nervous frighten selfish shake clog incumbrance trust behave good make useful think good go content go ready heaven protect

paragraph: "No, ma'am," replied Ready, "William will do just as well.  Indeed, I would go by myself with pleasure; but we know not what the day may bring forth.  I might be taken ill--I might hurt myself--I am an old man, you know; and then I was thinking that if any accident was to happen to me, you might miss me--that's all."
tokens: reply ready do go pleasure know day bring take ill hurt old man know think accident happen miss

paragraph: "Pardon me," replied Mrs Seagrave; "a mother is foolish at times."
tokens: pardon reply mother foolish time

paragraph: "Over-anxious, ma'am, perhaps, but not foolish," replied Ready.
tokens: anxious foolish reply ready

paragraph: "Well, then, William shall go with you, Ready;--that point's settled," observed Mr Seagrave: "what is the next?"
tokens: go ready point settle observe next

paragraph: "The next is to prepare for our journey.  We must take some provisions and water with us, a gun and some ammunition, a large axe for me, and one of the hatchets for William; and, if you please, Romulus and Remus had better come with us.  Juno, put a piece of beef and a piece of pork into the pot.  William, will you fill four quart bottles with water, while I sew up a knapsack out of canvas for each of us?"
tokens: next prepare journey take provision water gun ammunition large axe hatchet come put piece beef piece pork pot fill quart bottle water sew knapsack canvas

paragraph: "And what shall I do, Ready?" said Mr Seagrave.
tokens: do ready say

paragraph: "Why, sir, if you will sharpen the axe and the hatchet on the grindstone, it would be of great service, and Tommy can turn it, he is so fond of work."
tokens: sir sharp axe hatchet grindstone great service turn fond work

paragraph: Tommy jumped up directly; he was quite strong enough to turn the grindstone, but he was much fonder of play than work; but as Ready had said that he was fond of it, he wished to prove that such was the case, and worked very hard.  Before they went to prayers and retired for the night, the axe was sharpened, the knapsacks made, and everything else ready.
tokens: jump strong turn grindstone fonder play work ready say fond wish prove such case work go prayer retire night axe sharpen knapsack make ready

paragraph: "When do you intend to start, Ready?" said Mr Seagrave.
tokens: intend start ready say

paragraph: "Why, sir, I should like to get off at the dawn of day, when the heat is not so great."
tokens: sir like get dawn day heat great

paragraph: "And when do you intend to come back?" said Mrs Seagrave.
tokens: intend come say

paragraph: "Why, madam, we have provisions enough for three days: if we start to-morrow morning, which is Wednesday, I hope to be back some time on Friday evening; but I won't be later than Saturday morning if I can help it."
tokens: madam have provision day start morning hope time evening late morning help

paragraph: "Good-night--and good-bye, mother," said William, "for I shall not see you to-morrow!"
tokens: good night good mother say see

paragraph: "God bless and protect you, my dear child!" replied Mrs Seagrave. "Take care of him, Ready, and good-bye to you till we meet."
tokens: bless protect dear child reply take care ready good bye meet

paragraph: Mrs Seagrave went into the tent to hide the tears which she could not suppress.
tokens: go tent hide tear suppress
